title: welsh conservatives appoint new leader senedd
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe party has acted quickly to replace Paul Davies MS, who stepped down yesterday amid the ongoing controversy caused by the allegations of drinking alcohol in the Senedd in December.Andrew RT Davies, South Wales Central MS, from Cowbridge, has held the post previously, but stepped down himself two-and-a-half years ago amid mounting pressure from within the party.And just two weeks ago, he was the subject of demands for suspension - by among others, deputy Labour Party leader Angela Rayner MP - over comments in a tweet in regard to the US Capitol riot, in which he compared protesters there to those who supported a second referendum on Brexit.Of his reappointment, he said today: ldquoBecoming leader of the Welsh Conservatives in the Senedd once again is a great honour and privilege, and Im pleased to enjoy the unanimous support of my colleagues to take us forward after a dficult few days for us all.ldquoOn behalf of the Group I want to pay tribute to Paul Davies for his service as leader. Paul is not only a colleague but a trusted friend, who has served his constituents and party with distinction, and will continue to do so.ldquoThere is urgent work in front of all of us and our immediate focus will be continuing to hold the Labour administration in the Senedd to account on vital issues such as the vaccine rollout, and fighting Mays election alongside our excellent slate of candidates and dedicated volunteers.ldquoWe are in a moment like no other, and the COVID- pandemic has sadly only served to shine a spotlight on the challenges in peoplersquos everyday lives challenges that have been made all the harder by twenty of Welsh Labour Government failure.ldquoFrom our fragile economy to ever increasing NHS waiting lists, people in Wales have been badly let down by successive Labour administrations. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe story of St Dwynwens Day" Who is St Dwynwen and why does Wales have its own Valentines Day St Dwynwen, the patron saint of Welsh lovers, celebrates her feast day on Sundayltspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgt, January .lt spangtlt spangt" Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl" href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentTODAY is January , which may not seem like a special day - but it is actually St Dwynwenrsquos Day ndash the Welsh Valentinersquos Day.It is a celebrated day in most parts of Wales, but why does Wales have a separate day of love and who is the inspiration for the day Valentines Day is celebrated on February  all over the world. St Valentine is the Roman patron saint of lovers as well as epileptics and beekeepers. He was said to be a Roman priest and physician who suffered martyrdom - welcoming death rather than denouncing his faith - during the persecution of Christians by emperor Claudius II Gothicus in around . He is said to have died on February  of that year and Valentines Day has been celebrated since approximately the th century.While the Welsh also celebrate Valentines Day, there is the Welsh equivalent - celebrating St Dwynwen - three weeks earlier on January . It is a popular celebration among Welsh speakers in the land, but it is becoming more widely popular across Wales, with the people of Wales professing their love to their loved ones in January.MORE NEWS:Who was St Dwynwen St Dwynwen was a Welsh princess who lived in the fourth century in what we know now as the Brecon Beacons National Park. She is the Welsh patron saint of lovers ndash despite being quite unlucky in love herself.She was said to be the prettiest of King Brychan Brycheiniogrsquos  daughters and fell in love with prince Maelon Dafodrill. To her dismay, her father had already arranged for her to marry someone .She was so upset and begged God to make her forget her love. During her sleep, she was visited by an angel carrying a sweet potion that was designed to erase all memory of Maelon and turn the prince into a block of ice.God then gave the princess three wishes. She first wished that her prince be thawed. Her second wish was that God meets the hopes and dreams of true lovers. Her final wish was that she should never marry.God granted her these three wishes and as a mark of thanks, she devoted her le to him, becoming a nun and founding a convent on Llanddwyn, located off the west coast of Anglesey. Remains of the church ndash which had a well named after Dwynwen ndash can still be seen today. The well and convent became a place of pilgrimage after her death in AD. Visitors believed that the sacred fish or eels in the well could foretell whether the visitors relationship would be happy and whether love and happiness would be theirs.She is also the patron saint of sick and injured animals. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a commentOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... title: vaughan gething review lockdown restrictions wales

These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe Welsh Government is due to review the restrictions this week, with first minister Mark Drakeford announcing the outcome of this on Friday.But Mr Gething said although there was ldquogood news in reduced transmission rates and declining hospital admission rates, coronavirus still poses a ldquosignicant risk in Wales.:ldquoWe look at all of the dferent matters available to us, but, as I said last week, no one should expect a signicant unlocking of the current lockdown measures, he said. ldquoThey are what are keeping us safe, it is helping to drive down the overall transmission rate ndash wersquore now at just under  cases per , for the figures just released today.ldquoNow thats good news to see it coming down but theres still quite a high level of coronavirus circulating, and our positivity rate is still well above the  per cent mark to consider moving beyond that, as well as the fact that our NHS is still under lots and lots of pressure.ldquoIn our hospitals, even though were seeing a decline in admission rates, our critical care units are now operating at still about  per cent of their normal capacity.ldquoTheres a range of dferent things to consider and I hope people will be patient and still do the right thing and recognise that there is still a signicant risk to all of us. We have to do the right thing, which may mean that our measures have to be extended for some time to come, but no one should expect a signicant change in the arrangements or a signicant easing of those arrangements at the end of this week.The health minister was also asked about reports the lockdown restrictions may be eased in England, and whether a four-nation approach to easing the lockdown would be preferred.ldquoIts helpful for us to discuss these matters sensibly with each other, he said. ldquoThere is now much more regular engagement between the four governments, thatrsquos with the first ministers are meeting together with Michael Gove for the UK Government.ldquoWe havent had that direct engagement between the first ministers of not just Wales but also Scotland, Northern Ireland and Boris Johnson as prime minister, I think that would help us to do so.ldquoI hope that as it becomes a more real possibility will be able to have a grown up and constructive conversation between all four governments in the UK. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a commentOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... had been donated by friends and family.Last year, two of the trustees arranged for twenty boxes of used Lego and Duplo, which had also been donated, to be shipped to Lesotho and then went out to distribute it around the schools and give training on its use to the teachers.A very special relationship developed with two organisations in particular ndash the TY Junior Academy, a residential school founded by Godfrey Kakande and run now by his daughter Irene Nagingo, and St Ceciliarsquos Orphanage and Centre for Teenage Mothers run by Father Augustine Mahlaku.Father Augustine Mahlaku at St Ceciliarsquos Church ndash during the welcome for the Youth Group in Much of the fundraising has been for these two places, although the charity has also financed drought relief and the training of a nurse, supported a clinic in the capital of Maseru, and helped Growing Nations which aims to teach sustainable agriculture to young people.MORE NEWS:At the school, the Trust has been able to fund the building of a kitchen, a library and refurbishment of classrooms and at St Ceciliarsquos money has been sent to build a meeting room and purchase agricultural equipment and supplies.This will be They took photos and came back to the site with Lilys mum, Sally, and baby brother George.Mrs Wilder, said: ldquoLily likes dinosaurs, especially her pterodactyl toy, and was so excited about her discovery."She spotted a footprint in the rocks and it looked amazing we werent sure it it was real so I shared a photo on a Facebook group and had a huge response." "The dinosaur footprint trace fossil discovered by Lily Wilder Realising the signicance of Lilys discovery, Mrs Wilder contacted National Museum Wales, who advised her to take down the post to avoid a stampede of fossil fans descending on the protected section of land.The -mm trace fossil has now been legally removed, after permission was granted by the landowners and Natural Resources Wales, and is currently in safe-keeping.The trace fossil, believed to be around  million years old, will be taken to National Museum Wales, in Cardf, on a temporary or permanent basis.Lily, who now plans to get more dinosaur toys, will forever be named as the footprint fossils finder and will be invited into the museum once coronavirus restrictions allow it to re-open.Although this isnt the first fossil discovered in Barry, it is so well-preserved that experts are in awe.Palaeontology Curator of National Museum Wales, Cindy Howells, who arranged for the legal removal of the footprint, said: ldquoThis is a spectacular discovery.ldquoItrsquos the best-preserved trace fossil thatrsquos ever been found in South Wales ndash normally theyrsquore hollow or less well defined, but on this one you can see the claws and the points at the end.ldquoThis discovery is unique and worth protecting ndash we will be studying the footprint and it will teach us a lot more about dinosaur feet and their bone and muscle structure. "The dinosaur footprint trace fossil discovered by Lily Wilder The footprint is believed to be that of a meat-eating theropod from the early days when dinosaurs were first starting to evolve, around  million years after dinosaurs first emerged on Earth.ldquoImagine a little fierce hunter and scavenger, with lots of sharp teeth, running around the shore, added Ms Howells.This lsquoabsolutely amazingrsquo discovery has also been praised by archaeologist, Karl-James Langford MLitt, of Archaeology Cymru, who has videos of the fossil in situ, before it was removed, on his YouTube channelMr Langford, who found a dinosaur footprint at Bendricks Beach eight years ago, said: ldquoLily needs all the credit for this absolutely amazing find it will be something she remembers for the rest of her days.ldquoOnce itrsquos in the museum she can go and see it and say lsquoI found that."It was so brilliant to see this internationally important find. title: wales chief medical officer calls unified public health
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityTodayDr Atherton published his annual report which reflects on Walesrsquo initial actions in response to the pandemic, from early  until the end of the summer.Other key lessons, he said, centred around environmental issues, more focus on innovation and the importance of investment in health protection.In his report, Dr Atherton says: ldquo As with the rest of the world, in Wales we have had to respond to the signicant threat posed by this pandemic, to our health, social care and wellbeing, our employment and education systems, our economy, and in fact every aspect of our lives.ldquoIn light of the events of , I have decided to produce a special report reflecting on how we in Wales have faced the challenge of the pandemic together, and how we can seek to come out of this grave situation stronger and better prepared to tackle some of the challenges we were already facing and those of the future.ldquoCovid- reminds us we do not live in isolation and that it is all too easy to be impacted, almost without warning, by global events.ldquoIt reminds us how interconnected we are to our environment and those that share with us.ldquoWe must therefore take forward what we have learned and use it to revaluate our relationships with the planet, and with each other, and to say that we will no longer tolerate avoidable inequalities and short-term environmental planning.ldquoFrom tragic circumstances we may yet grasp opportunities we may never have again.The report makes eight recommendationsFocus on investment in health protection servicesContinue to review the effectiveness ofcase management and contact tracing systemsTake the learning from the pandemic and apply it to preparations for any future crisesEngage fully with the public on response to the pandemic and the measures being put in placeAdopt a whole of society lsquoone healthrsquo approach to a number of dficult issues, including climate change, zoonoses, and antimicrobial resistanceMaintain innovation and creativity in health and social care delivery, and priortise sustaining the wellbeing of all key workersFocus on health inequities in all policiesFocus on ongoing research needed into the long-term effects of Covid-Health minister Vaughan Gething added: ldquoThis pandemic is not over. whether she would join Strictly Come Dancing or Irsquom A Celebrityhellip Get Me Out Of Here!, Ms Weaver said: ldquoIrsquom not quite sure the nation is ready for me to take part in Strictly.ldquoThat may just be too much for people in lockdown.But she added: ldquoNever say never.A clip of the December  meeting, which was put on Twitter on Thursday afternoon, had been viewed more than three million times by Friday morning, much to the shock of Ms Weaver.She told BBC Radio Fourrsquos Womanrsquos Hour: ldquoI suppose the surprise comes in large part because actually .% ndash thatrsquos an actual fact Irsquom sure ndash of council meetings are just not like that.ldquoThey are often less exciting than we might hope they were.The meeting of the parish council in Cheshire marked the second time Mr Tolver had been removed, having previously been evicted from the earlier pm planning and environment committee call.In the .pm extraordinary meeting, Mr Tolver told Ms Weaver, chief officer of the Cheshire Association of Local Councils , to ldquostop talking, and added: ldquoYou have no authority here.In response, Ms Weaver removed Mr Tolver from the Zoom call and placed him in a virtual waiting room.Mr Tolver told the PA news agency: ldquoI cannot think of any other council meeting anywhere, that was taken over by an unqualied member of the public like this.ldquoRemoving half the councillors from the meeting denied half of the voters of the village from being represented ndash it was an appalling attack on their democratic rights.irsquove never missed in person meetings more sure who was in charge, she told Womanrsquos Hour.ldquoButyou want the boring details, we have two councillors who have legitimately called a meetinghellip and at that point my job in supporting them title: top dj run  hour online rave aid pips
story: Man taken to hospital after serious crash   ‘Birdman’ Leslie Harrison has died suddenlyNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleCarsHomes and GardensPublic NoticesAdvertise My BusinessNewsPeopleTop DJ to run  hour online rave in aid of PIPSA top DJ, who has played nightclubs from Ibiza to New York, is to run a  hour online rave to raise funds for mental health charity PIPS.By Carmel RobinsonThursday, th February , : pm  "       "  Mike Callan, a well known DJ in the nightle scene for  years, is to run the DJ set tomorrow night.He is hoping for a spectacular turnout to lt the Lockdown blues and raise some much needed funds for local charity PIPS.Mike, who has most recently had residencies in Belfast and Portadown, says music has played a massive part in his le and believes music can help lt everyone’s spiritis."DJ Mike Callan.He has seen the effects the COVID restrictions has had on many of his friends in the industry.“For most of them the music industry is all they had and now without it many of them are struggling with their mental health,” said the -year-old father of two daughters who lives in Tandragee.His we Sarah said: “During the lockdowns Mike started doing livestreams on Facebook for people to tune in, hoping it would lt peoples spirits, but he wanted to do more than that.“He thought his livestreams could do a bit more so he has set up a charity event for PIPS, an organization that provides responsive care to those in need and also provide support for those bereaved by suicide. “Many charities have been effected by the restrictions so outdoor fundraising events have not been possible. “Mental health is on the rise and PIPS provides a much needed service but they need people like Mike to help. Raising funds for PIPS will help them continue their work.”Mike, who is originally from Dundalk, started working at a nightclub collecting glasses aged . He was instantly hooked on the nightle industry. The nightclub got a massive refurbishment and a state of the art lighting system and the club used to fly a guy from England to control the lights.Sarah revealed: “Mike used to watch everything the guy was doing. “One weekend the guy didn’t show up and the owners were freaking out and Mike stepped up and said he knew what to do, the owners asked him to demonstrate and he pulled it off. “At  this was his first job inside a DJ box, so he started building his music collection, going to Dublin, Newry and Belfast to buy records. “At  he started running raves in a small nightclub every Saturday night. At , after his leaving cert exams he was off to Ibiza,” said Sarah.Since then he has worked at clubs in Belfast such as La Lea, Milk, Event Horizon, Eivissa, El Divino. He also worked in Euphoria in Portadown was Eurphoria and the Cellar Bar in Lurgan.Mike will start his  hour Dj set in aid of PIPS on Friday the th of February at pm and finish on Saturday at pm. It will be streamed live on Mixcloud for anyone to see. He picked this date as it is Mental Health week. To join in check it out hereIf you would like to donate, click hereEditor’s Message:Thank you for reading this article. title: council agrees plans centenary celebrations
story: Tributes to ‘highly esteemed’ Drumcree Orangeman Darryl Hewitt   ‘Birdman’ Leslie Harrison has died suddenlyNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleCarsHomes and GardensPublic NoticesAdvertise My BusinessNewsPoliticsCouncil agrees plans for Centenary celebrationsMembers of Armagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon Borough Council have voted in favour of Council’s plans to mark Northern Ireland’s th anniversary.By The NewsroomThursday, th January , : am  "       "  The decision to support the plans, as recommended by Council’s economic development and regeneration committee, was taken at December’s monthly meeting of Council.A proposal to reject the committee’s recommendation was put forward on the night by Sinn Fein group leader Councillor Liam Mackle and seconded by his party colleague, Councillor Paul Duffy.Formative plans for the celebrations were first brought to Council’s economic development and regeneration committee in November, where unionist members of the committee were unhappy with what was presented."Craigavon Civic CentreAt the time, DUP Alderman Stephen Moutray told officers they should be “embarrassed” by the contents of the report and a proposal from Councillor Mark Baxter, seconded by Alderman Ian Burns, saw officers redraw their plans.Revised plans were brought before the committee in December with two options, both with an allocated budget of £, put to members.DUP group leader Mark Baxter proposed that option one was supported by Council and this proposal was seconded by UUP Alderman Ian Burns.All DUP and UUP members of the committee voted in favour of the proposal with all SDLP and Sinn Fein councillors voting against .The committeeChair, Alliance Party councillor Brian Pope abstained from the vote. As a result, Cllr Baxter’s proposal passed with  votes in favour, eight against and one abstention recorded.However, upon discussion of the committee meeting’s minutes at December’s meeting of full council, Councillor Liam Mackle proposed that Council did not accept the recommendation put forward by the committee.This proposal was seconded by his party colleague Councillor Paul Duffy.Councillor Pope said it “was very important” that the occasion is marked and noted the need for education and cultural events to be spread throughout the borough.He also expressed his concerns about budgets and the idea of a large event taking place giving the current pandemic.“I would propose we accept the original recommendationfrom the November committee that listed the programme, including the £, budget,” said Cllr Pope. This proposal was seconded by his party’s group leader, Councillor Eoin Tennyson.Speaking about the issue, Cllr Tennyson said the programme had been discussed atand explained, from his perspective, initialdiscussions were constructive.“All parties engaged with a view to marking the centenary in a way that was inclusive and respectful,” said Cllr Tennyson. “I think the original recommendation that was presented by officers to the committee was one that did that.“It would allow us to mark the centenary in a way that was inclusive and reflective of the entire borough and also balanced against the need to be prudent in terms of the financial situation we as a council and indeed many of our rate payers are in.“I can’t in good conscience support a proposal that would see this council commit to an additional £, unbudgeted spend. The reality is that money is going to have be found through the estimates process.“We could end up in the situation where that money will have to be found through a rates hike or cuts to services. I think Councillor Pope’s proposal is an eminently sensible one and I hope all parties can see it in themselves to support that approach.”DUP councillor Darryn Causby sought clarity on what was being proposed andthe proposals tabled complied with standing orders.“Under standing order .. there should only be one amendment moved and discussed at one time, the same applies for proposals on the floor,” said Cllr Causby.“There was one on the floor, Cllr Pope then put a second one on the floor but can I please get clarity on the first one [Cllr Mackle’s proposal] it seems to be a direct negative of what is in the papers and under standing orders I am not clear on whether that is acceptable.“The other point I would raise is the budget was actually agreed at the November council meeting and we just ratied that a short time ago.“If someone is not happy with that, I suggest they look through standing orders and bring a rescinding motion to change that decision.”At this point Council’s Lord Mayor, Councillor Kevin Savage informed members he needed to speak with Council’s Chief Executive Roger Wilson and muted his microphone.Following his confidential discussionwith Mr Wilson, the Lord Mayor confirmed the budget had already been agreed before putting Councillor Mackle’s proposal, to reject the recommendation put forward by the committee, to the floor.All unionist councillors present voted against the proposal as did the three members of the Alliance Party. The members of Sinn Fein and the SDLP voted in favour of the proposal.With the votes totalled, the proposal was defeated with  members voting against the proposal and  voting in favour.The Lord Mayor then explainedthat as the recommendation of the committee stands, a rescinding motion would be requiredbefore Cllr Tennyson’s proposal could be heard.Councillor Tennyson said he was not sure he agreed with this interpretation.“The proposal was that we proceed with the programme originallyproposed by officers not the budget,” said Cllr Tennyson.“The budget may have been agreed, the programme has never been agreed therefore a rescinding motion is not required.“We have proposed that we proceed with the originalprogramme as proposed to the economic development and regeneration committee, it just so happened to be at a cost of £,.“I would be quite keen for that to be voted on as I do not share the analysis that a rescinding motion is required for a decision that has never been taken.”Councillor Baxter then said that as a matter of process given that Cllr Mackle’s proposal has fallen by “default the recommendation goes through”.“I do note Alliance are quite clearly trying to claw back as they could not bring themselves to vote for the celebration of Northern Ireland at the last committee meeting,” said Cllr Baxter.“By the very fact Cllr Mackle’s proposal has failed this recommendation from the committee is going through.”The Lord Mayor said that was his understanding as well and the recommendation as it stands has now gone through.A proposal to accept the minutes of the committee was put forward by Councillor Brian Pope and seconded by SDLP group leader, Councillor Thomas O’Hanlon.Editor’s message:Thank you for reading this article. title: nichola daly the importance of voices for business at this time
story: LAST Sunday morning, coffee in hand, I sat down to watch Sunday politics to keep abreast of latest developments and reviewing the topics of the week. Business support was a key topic, and it was devastating to hear Tina McKenzie, Chair of the Federation of Small Businesses, discuss the hardships being faced and demonstrating the very bleak outlook for many businesseswe do not find a way forward both in terms of the handling of the pandemic,but also enhancing the support available to these businesses. The impact on business is substantial and that on each of their employees is devastating. Furlough has been a hottopic during this lockdown and as we have seen business vilied for not looking atrestructures, she reminded us of the fact that whilst the support available is welcomed, itremains far from enough to enable survival. I recently received an email from a local politician who stated, “I’m in awe you are still in business”. While this could be accepted as a compliment, this is far from the support andvoice a small business like mine requires or is looking for, and this was conveyed to them. The business community needs a clear voice with a key message and desire, rather than noise. These voices, like Tina, work tirelessly to press the government to step in with moresupport, minimising their costs and contribution while revenues are non-existent, and Iapplaud them for doing so. With news breaking this week that there is still pound million remaining in the Stormont COVID “pot” to be allocated towards businesses before March, I would urge Diane Doddsand Conor Murphy to listen to businesses and their representatives to ensure businessessurvive. It would be truly shamefulthis money had to be ed to Westminster as a result of poor planning and slow reactions, while local businesses are making very dficultdecisions due to lack of financial support which clearly is available, but not utilised. With financial survival for businesses and more importantly each of us as iniduals and our families the sole aim, Tina succinctly reminded us that our elected representatives should beheld to account, not the businesses themselves. The Sunday Times recently reported that the public feels more frightened now than at any time before with % of voters feeling ‘personally threatened’ by COVID. It also reportedthat Boris Johnson and Rishi Sunak have agreed on a ‘recovery plan’ to save jobs. The realityis however, thatthey and our own Executive do not deliver this strategy correctly, without delay or U-turn, the job market will constrict further. Many professional trade bodies arereporting that their members don’t have enough in the bank until April and judging bynumerous reports this past week, lockdown and on-going restrictions are likely to extend beyond April. How can businesses be expected to survive without this  We all have a voice, but not all of us use it. As a business community we need vocal and active business leaders to speak out to help fight our case. A great demonstrative exampleof this is the great work of my good friend Brian Donaldson from Excluded NI. Throughout,Brian has spoken out and acted to help thousands who have been financially excluded with no support being provided to them. Brian had established himself as newly self-employedchef just before lockdown, only to find that as support packages were announced, he quickly found himself excluded from all government support offered. With a family, and amortgage to pay, Brian created a  for his case to constructively find a resolution forall those who found themselves in the same situation. By working closely with local politicians, Brian, has researched and submitted proposals to the Department for the Economy with numerous resolutions and proposals to deliver financialassistance to these groups, which has resulted in thousands, including Ltd Company directors,eventually being awarded some financial support. Brian continues daily to ensure the excluded have a voice and shows how being a voice can bring about change! As a business owner, I send a huge thank you to all the hard-working professional trade bodies and voices for our communities, who throughout this time have worked tirelessly toensure we all have all have a business toto in the future. If you, like so many, are in adficult situation, be sure to reach out to your local business trade body today to highlight your plight and use their voices as much as you can. We all need as much support andsurvival mechanism as possible. It’s evident that the more voices there are and the louderthey become successful outcomes can be delivered. I will wrap up by leaving you with a well-known quote by Napoleon Bonaparte: ‘Ten people who speak make more noise than ten thousand who are silent’. Until next week, stay safe! title: paul watters smoked salmon and potato pancake
story: OUR resident chef, Paul Watters has been back in the kitchen and this week he has come up with a tasty recipe for a smoked salmon and potato pancake. Heres how you can make it and what you need to serve it up!  Pancake mix - serves   egg  cup of self raising flour  potato peeled and grated   bunch of spring onions Salt and pepper  cup of milk  For the salad  bag of mixed leaf salad salad  cherry tomatoes    red onion sliced  packet of smoked salmon   Cream cheese mix  tablespoons of cream cheese  tablespoons of wholegrain mustard  To make the pancakes Transfer the grated potatoes to a dry tea towel and squeeze any excess water out. Transfer to a large bowl. Break in the egg and mix well, add the flour and mix again. Slowly add spring onion and gradually add milk . Heat a large non stick pan to the stove bring up to a medium heat. Drizzle in a little oil . Add approximately one tablespoon of the mix and cook for approximately three minutes each side until golden brown. Repeat For the poached egg bring a small saucepan with   pint of water to the boil, add one tablespoon of white vinegar or the juice of one lemon and a pinch of salt. Whisk it together - this will create a whirlpool effect. Add in your egg and take off the heat.
